conversation.content: [breathlessly] I can't believe you actually called me after, [shocked], three years of nothing, but thank God you did because that leopard is, [trembling], critically endangered.
[defensive] Look, um, I didn't call to reconnect or anything, I just, well, figured you'd want to know about your, [bitter], precious animal before it dies up here in the cold, you know.

[urgent] Where exactly did you find her, um, because she's been missing for, [anxious], three days and we thought she'd headed south toward the, er, warmer valleys not up into the, [shaky voice], ski territory. [pause]
[quietly] She's behind the maintenance shed near lift seven, um, barely breathing and there's, [worried], blood on the snow, I mean, a lot of it.
[desperate] Did you, um, check if she's conscious because, well, we need to know if she'll, [hesitantly], attack when we approach her.
Her eyes track movement but she can't, [exhausted], lift her head and she made this sound when I got close, [whispering], like a broken purr.
That means she's going into shock and we have maybe, [panicked], twenty minutes before her organs start shutting down, [speeding up], assuming the cold hasn't already damaged them.

[reluctantly] I, um, wrapped her in emergency blankets from the ski patrol station and, well, tried to stop the bleeding with, [improvising], gauze from the first aid kit but I don't, er, know if I'm making things worse. [sigh]
[grateful] You did exactly the right thing, keeping her warm is, [relieved], crucial, and the pressure on the wound probably saved her life.
[surprised] Wait, you're actually, um, complimenting me on something, I mean, that's a first since, well, [sarcastically], dad's funeral where you called me irresponsible.

[regretful] This isn't the time to, um, rehash our family drama but, [apologetic], maybe I was wrong about some things, er, especially seeing how you've, [warm], handled this situation today. [clearing throat]
[softly] She reminds me of that stuffed snow leopard you had, [nostalgic], in your room when we were kids, the one you said would protect us from nightmares.

[tearfully] You remember that old thing after all these, [choked up], years of pretending we never shared a childhood, [emotional], never shared anything that mattered before everything fell apart between us.

[honest] I remember everything, um, including how you always dreamed of, [melancholic], working with big cats and, well, how proud I was when you got the zoo job even though I never, er, [trailing off], told you...
[firmly] After we save her, after she's stable and safe, [determined], we need to have a real conversation about us.
[nervous] Yeah, I suppose running into each other over a dying snow leopard is, [wry], probably the universe telling us something.
The rescue team is five minutes out so just keep, [gently], talking to her because she needs to hear calm voices, [reassuring], know that she's not alone out there.
I've been telling her about the view from up here, how the, [peaceful], morning light hits the peaks and makes everything look like her natural habitat, [thoughtful], like home.
You know, um, that's exactly what I would have, [touched], told her too.
Maybe we're not as different as we, um, pretended to be all these years, [hopeful], huh? [laugh softly]
